speaker: dromio eph.
text: sir, he din'd with her there, at the porpentine.

speaker: courtier
text: he did, and from my finger snatch'd that ring.

speaker: antipholus eph.
text: 'tis true, my liege; this ring i had of her.

speaker: duke
text: saw'st thou him enter at the abbey here?

speaker: courtier
text: as sure, my liege, as i do see your grace.

speaker: duke
text: why, this is strange. go call the abbess hither.

speaker: ægeon
text: most mighty duke, vouchsafe me speak a word: haply i see a friend will save my life, and pay the sum that may deliver me.

speaker: duke
text: speak freely, syracusian, what thou wilt.

speaker: ægeon
text: is not your name, sir, called antipholus? and is not that your bondman dromio?

speaker: dromio eph.
text: within this hour i was his bondman, sir; but he, i thank him, gnaw'd in two my cords: now am i dromio and his man, unbound.

speaker: ægeon
text: i am sure you both of you remember me.

speaker: dromio eph.
text: ourselves we do remember, sir, by you; for lately we were bound, as you are now. you are not pinch's patient, are you, sir?

speaker: ægeon
text: why look you strange on me? you know me well.

speaker: antipholus eph.
text: i never saw you in my life till now.

speaker: ægeon
text: o! grief hath chang'd me since you saw me last, and careful hours, with time's deformed hand, have written strange defeatures in my face: but tell me yet, dost thou not know my voice?

speaker: antipholus eph.
text: neither.

speaker: ægeon
text: dromio, nor thou?

speaker: dromio eph.
text: no, trust me, sir, not i.

speaker: ægeon
text: i am sure thou dost.

speaker: dromio eph.
text: ay, sir; but i am sure i do not; and whatsoever a man denies, you are now bound to believe him.

speaker: ægeon
text: not know my voice! o, time's extremity, hast thou so crack'd and splitted my poor tongue in seven short years, that here my only son knows not my feeble key of untun'd cares? though now this grained face of mine be hid in sap-consuming winter's drizzled snow, and all the conduits of my blood froze up, yet hath my night of life some memory, my wasting lamps some fading glimmer left, my dull deaf ears a little use to hear: all these old witnesses, i cannot err, tell me thou art my son antipholus.

speaker: antipholus eph.
text: i never saw my father in my life.

speaker: ægeon
text: but seven years since, in syracusa, boy, thou know'st we parted: but perhaps, my son, thou sham'st to acknowledge me in misery.

speaker: antipholus eph.
text: the duke and all that know me in the city can witness with me that it is not so: i ne'er saw syracusa in my life.

speaker: duke
text: i tell thee, syracusian, twenty years have i been patron to antipholus, during which time he ne'er saw syracusa. i see thy age and dangers make thee dote.

speaker: abbess
text: most mighty duke, behold a man much wrong'd.

speaker: adriana
text: i see two husbands, or mine eyes deceive me!

speaker: duke
text: one of these men is genius to the other; and so of these: which is the natural man, and which the spirit? who deciphers them?

speaker: dromio syr.
text: i, sir, am dromio: command him away.

speaker: dromio eph.
text: i, sir, am dromio: pray let me stay.

speaker: antipholus syr.
text: ægeon art thou not? or else his ghost?

speaker: dromio syr.
text: o! my old master; who hath bound him here?

speaker: abbess
text: whoever bound him, i will loose his bonds, and gain a husband by his liberty. speak, old ægeon, if thou be'st the man that hadst a wife once call'd æmilia, that bore thee at a burden two fair sons. o! if thou be'st the same ægeon, speak, and speak unto the same æmilia!

speaker: ægeon
text: if i dream not, thou art æmilia: if thou art she, tell me where is that son that floated with thee on the fatal raft?

speaker: abbess
text: by men of epidamnum, he and i, and the twin dromio, all were taken up: but by and by rude fishermen of corinth by force took dromio and my son from them, and me they left with those of epidamnum. what then became of them, i cannot tell; i to this fortune that you see me in.

speaker: duke
text: why, here begins his morning story right: these two antipholus', these two so like, and these two dromios, one in semblance, besides her urging of her wrack at sea; these are the parents to these children, which accidentally are met together. antipholus, thou cam'st from corinth first?

speaker: antipholus syr.
text: no, sir, not i; i came from syracuse.

speaker: duke
text: stay, stand apart; i know not which is which.

speaker: antipholus eph.
text: i came from corinth, my most gracious lord,—

speaker: dromio eph.
text: and i with him.

speaker: antipholus eph.
text: brought to this town by that most famous warrior, duke menaphon, your most renowned uncle.

speaker: adriana
text: which of you two did dine with me to-day?

speaker: antipholus syr.
text: i, gentle mistress.

speaker: adriana
text: and are not you my husband?

speaker: antipholus eph.
text: no; i say nay to that.

speaker: antipholus syr.
text: and so do i; yet did she call me so; and this fair gentlewoman, her sister here, did call me brother.

speaker: angelo
text: that is the chain, sir, which you had of me.

speaker: antipholus syr.
text: i think it be, sir; i deny it not.

speaker: antipholus eph.
text: and you, sir, for this chain arrested me.

speaker: angelo
text: i think i did, sir; i deny it not.

speaker: adriana
text: i sent you money, sir, to be your bail, by dromio; but i think he brought it not.

speaker: dromio eph.
text: no, none by me.

speaker: antipholus syr.
text: this purse of ducats i receiv'd from you, and dromio, my man, did bring them me. i see we still did meet each other's man, and i was ta'en for him, and he for me, and thereupon these errors are arose.

speaker: antipholus eph.
text: these ducats pawn i for my father here.

speaker: duke
text: it shall not need: thy father hath his life.

speaker: courtier
text: sir, i must have that diamond from you.

speaker: antipholus eph.
text: there, take it; and much thanks for my good cheer.

speaker: abbess
text: renowned duke, vouchsafe to take the pains to go with us into the abbey here, and hear at large discoursed all our fortunes; and all that are assembled in this place, that by this sympathized one day's error have suffer'd wrong, go keep us company, and we shall make full satisfaction. thirty-three years have i but gone in travail of you, my sons; and, till this present hour my heavy burdens ne'er delivered. the duke, my husband, and my children both, and you the calendars of their nativity, go to a gossip's feast, and joy with me: after so long grief such festivity!

speaker: duke
text: with all my heart i'll gossip at this feast.

speaker: dromio syr.
text: master, shall i fetch your stuff from shipboard?

speaker: antipholus eph.
text: dromio, what stuff of mine hast thou embark'd?

speaker: dromio syr.
text: your goods that lay at host, sir, in the centaur.

speaker: antipholus syr.
text: he speaks to me. i am your master, dromio: come, go with us; we'll look to that anon: embrace thy brother there; rejoice with him.

speaker: dromio syr.
text: there is a fat friend at your master's house, that kitchen'd me for you to-day at dinner: she now shall be my sister, not my wife.

speaker: dromio eph.
text: methinks you are my glass, and not my brother: i see by you i am a sweet-fac'd youth. will you walk in to see their gossiping?

speaker: dromio syr.
text: not i, sir; you are my elder.

speaker: dromio eph.
text: that's a question: how shall we try it?

speaker: dromio syr.
text: we'll draw cuts for the senior: till then lead thou first.

speaker: dromio eph.
text: nay, then, thus: we came into the world like brother and brother; and now let's go hand in hand, not one before another.
